Still working on the BQN-based compiler. How about ‚Äúgenerator‚Äù as a name for {} application? Sounds about as close to ‚Äúgeneric‚Äù as it actually is, and I feel like it does a good job of suggesting that it actually runs code when you call it. A f{}() function is a ‚Äúgenerated function‚Äù, and you‚Äôd probably call f a ‚Äúfunction generator‚Äù in the somewhat rare case when you pass it around rather than give it parameters immediately.

Compile-time definitions should use def, which doesn‚Äôt allow mutation, so I think this is no longer an issue. In an ordinary statement = always means runtime assignment.

How so? I‚Äôm thinking newLabel just requests a unique label ID. The function has a table connecting label IDs to instruction IDs, and populates it when label is called, all at compile time.
(what would a:= 5; a = 2+2; do? does the first a:= 5; completely change the behavior of all further a =s?)

I guess we should be able to do dead code elimination pretty easily in the IR, so it‚Äôs not really a problem if the index is computed but not used.

True. Also looks like the vector load/store operations don‚Äôt have indexed addressing modes, so it‚Äôs kind of pointless to use an index for the control for them. Maybe it would make the most sense to have a flag for exec to indicate whether the given index offsets pointers (as opposed to just being used as a value), or possibly a second exec function where it doesn‚Äôt?
in your loop definitions, e.g. for_scalar_tail would end up assigning weird numbers to the i variable in the loop - the iterated variable and pointer offset should be different parameters

Two significant changes to the syntax: I‚Äôm requiring fn(‚Ä¶) : type = {‚Ä¶ to have an = since typeGen{n} could be a valid type, and I‚Äôve made : a standalone character to avoid clumping it with = in :=, so :: can‚Äôt be used for parameter specification. I put in == instead but there are probably other options or approaches.
The infrastructure is in place for decent parse error reporting (parse stack with positions and expected/received), but a few bits aren‚Äôt hooked up making the output useless currently.
I think most of the remaining problems are that the AST definitions in nodes don‚Äôt quite match up with what‚Äôs generated, so RunNode fails to print the AST.

Got most of a BQN recursive-descent parser done today. Expressions are just lists of operations, names with parameters and arguments, etc. I‚Äôm thinking I can add some top-level statements to define operators and then finish parsing expressions in a second pass.

Maybe it would be better to have one function to generate a label, then two others to anchor it and (conditionally) jump to it. I guess we could also use symbols for labels, but they‚Äôd have to be function-scoped so it would be easy for them to conflict.

Not very relatedly, a refinement to my for-loop definition idea is that you could write control structures starting with a symbol, for instance @for (i to l) {‚Ä¶}. Define it with def @for (vars over i from a to b) block = and the language will match things up for you. This also works for def @if (cond) block = but not really for a while loop, since everything in the parens is passed by value and a while condition has to be reevaluated.

Hm, you can implement a for loop in terms of a block evaluator and goto. Not that we have to do it this way, but it‚Äôs nice to know it‚Äôs possible.

xxxxxxxxxx
 
for_copy{begin,end,vars,block} {
  i := begin
  loop = beginGoto{-1}          # backwards
  exit = beginGoto{1, i>=end}   # conditional forwards
  eval{i,vars,block}
  i = i+1
  endGoto{loop}  # unconditional
  endGoto{exit}
}

How about a definition like this? type{*v} is weird, but otherwise I think it makes sense.

xxxxxxxxxx
 
for_group{n}{init=0, len, vars, body} {
  l0 = len//n;  # Integer divide
  vec{v} = cast{*[n]type{*v}}
  for{0,  l0,  maptup{vec,vars}, body}

}

Tuples are quite useful in other places though: for example you might want to compare four pairs of [4]i32 registers and squash the results into a [16]u8 to call movemask on it. You can do this by putting the results in a 2!2![4]i32 register (or whatever the syntax is for making a tuple of the same type), and then calling a pack function between the two halves twice.

Oh, I think a concept we need is a tuple type, which functions that aren‚Äôt defined on tuples automatically map over. So the for loop takes a length and a tuple of pointers (possibly different types), and a function of mutable tuples. Syntax sugar constructs the tuples and function. Getting writes to work will be really tricky though.

No objections to the syntax, but I think it‚Äôs really important that it be possible to define for loops that follow the same syntax as the built-in one (although if this is possible, of course there‚Äôs no reason to actually have one built in). Really we‚Äôd like for it to be possible for a for loop to be a first-class value, so you can write code that accepts a loop as an argument and compile it for multiple architectures by varying the loop. So if they have a special syntax then there should also be a ‚Äúdefine for loop‚Äù construct.

Most permutes have the permutation hard-coded in the instruction, so that would be a few compile-time values and we don‚Äôt have to worry about their width. 64-bit permutevar uses 64-bit indices in [0,2) and shuffles within lanes; 32-bit permutevar uses 32-bit indices in [0,8) and goes across lanes. Gathers have 32 or 64 bits for both input and output; if one of those is smaller then it uses a half-register. Shuffle always uses one-byte indices and values, but you might want to use it for larger values, which you can do with a transformation like 2,1,0,3 into 4,5, 2,3 0,1, 6,7. The interpreter‚Äôs types are types, numbers (high-precision (like 64 bits) integers, probably), functions, and compile-time values. It‚Äôs dynamically-typed so functions just take in stuff and output a thing. I think there‚Äôs no reason for interpreter variables to be mutable. i=0, or whatever syntax we use, defines a variable both for the interpreter and in the compiled code, but i+=1 only affects i at runtime.
Expressions like [2*#$u64]i16 are purely interpreted, since the result is a type. For actual computation, say a = b+c, the interpreter does the type computation and also creates IR code.

We probably need to discuss the compile-time/runtime distinction. My thinking is that the compile-time is basically a simple interpreted language. Function calls use {params‚Ä¶}. Maybe the result is a () function and contains loops, but that doesn‚Äôt change the interpreter‚Äôs control flow.
[#$f32]u1 is a lot more flexible though. I think I would end up using variations like [#$i32]i8 a fair amount. And you should be able to define Mask{T} = [#$T]u1 anyway.
